metadata.question:
A man told his neighbor, “If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50.” The neighbor then purchased gasoline for the mower so he could mow the lawn. The neighbor wheeled his lawn mower to the man’s property and started the engine. At that moment, the man suddenly yelled, “I hereby revoke my offer.” If the neighbor thereafter mows the man’s lawn, will he recover the $50?

Yes, because the neighbor had begun the task before the man revoked his offer.
Yes, because the neighbor can sue for breach of oral contract.
No, because the man revoked his offer before the task was completed.
No, because the neighbor had done nothing more than prepare to accept the offer prior to the man’s revocation.
Yes, under the doctrine of quasi-contract.
Yes, because the neighbor had already incurred expenses in preparation to fulfill the contract.
No, because the man’s revocation was effective, since the neighbor had not completed performance.
No, because the neighbor did not get a written agreement from the man.
Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.
No, because there was no written contract and hence no legal obligation for the man to pay.

representative.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 from the man for mowing his lawn after the man revoked his offer?
representative.rule: In a unilateral contract, an offer becomes irrevocable once the offeree has begun performance. The offeror cannot revoke the offer after the offeree has started performing.
representative.application: The man's statement, 'If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50,' is an offer for a unilateral contract. The neighbor began performance by starting the engine of his lawn mower on the man's property. At this point, the offer became irrevocable, and the man's subsequent revocation was ineffective.
representative.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after the man revoked his offer when the neighbor had already commenced performance.
members.rule: In a unilateral contract, once the offeree begins performance, the offeror may not revoke the offer. An offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable once performance has begun.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract when he promised $50 in exchange for mowing his lawn. The neighbor accepted by beginning performance, evidenced by purchasing gasoline and starting the lawn mower. At this point, the offer became irrevocable, and the man could not revoke his offer.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor will recover the $50 as the offer for a unilateral contract became irrevocable once the neighbor commenced performance by starting the lawn mower.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after the man's revocation of an offer to mow the lawn, given the neighbor began performance.
members.rule: Under contract law, an offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance. The offeror cannot revoke the offer once the offeree has made substantial progress towards performance.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract by stating he would pay $50 if the neighbor mowed the lawn. The neighbor began performance by wheeling the mower to the man's property and starting the engine. At this point, the offer became irrevocable, as the neighbor's actions demonstrated a substantial beginning of performance.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50, because the unilateral contract offer became irrevocable when he began performing the task, prior to the man's attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after the man revoked his offer as the neighbor began to mow the lawn.
members.rule: In contract law, an offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance. The offeror cannot revoke the offer after substantial performance has begun.
members.application: The neighbor began performance by wheeling his mower to the man’s property and starting the engine. Under the rule governing unilateral contracts, this act constitutes the beginning of performance, thereby making the man's offer irrevocable at that point.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50 because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable when he began the performance by starting to mow the lawn.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover the $50 after the man revoked his offer as the neighbor began to mow the lawn.
members.rule: In contract law, an offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance. A unilateral contract is one where one party promises something in return for the act of the other party. Once the offeree starts performing, the offeror cannot revoke the offer.
members.application: In this scenario, the man's statement, 'If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50,' constitutes an offer for a unilateral contract where the act of mowing the lawn is the performance needed to accept the offer. The neighbor began to perform by starting the lawn mower on the man's property, which is a substantial commencement of performance. Therefore, under the rule regarding unilateral contracts, the man's attempt to revoke the offer at that point was ineffective.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50 because he began performance of the unilateral contract before the man revoked his offer, making the revocation ineffective.

representative.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 after the man revoked his offer when the neighbor had already begun performance?
representative.rule: In unilateral contracts, an offer becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance. The Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45 states that the beginning of performance creates an option contract, making the offer irrevocable until the task is completed.
representative.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract, which the neighbor accepted by beginning performance when he started the lawn mower. According to contract law, once performance begins, the offer cannot be revoked. Therefore, the offer became irrevocable when the neighbor began mowing, despite the man's attempt to revoke.
representative.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50 because the offer became irrevocable once the neighbor began performance, creating an obligation for the man to pay upon completion.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 after the man revoked his offer while the neighbor was in the process of accepting it by performance?
members.rule: Under contract law, an offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable once the offeree has begun performance. The Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45 states that the beginning of performance creates an option contract in which the offeror cannot revoke the offer until the offeree has been given a reasonable time to complete performance.
members.application: The neighbor started performing the task by wheeling his lawn mower to the man's property and starting the engine. According to the rule, once the neighbor began performance, the offer became irrevocable, and the man could not revoke it.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50 because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 after the man revoked an offer for a unilateral contract when the neighbor had already begun performance?
members.rule: Under contract law, an offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance. The Restatement (Second) of Contracts §45 states that when an offer invites an offeree to accept by rendering a performance, an option contract is created when the offeree begins the invited performance.
members.application: The man offered to pay $50 for mowing the lawn, a unilateral contract offer that becomes binding once the neighbor starts performing the task. The neighbor began performing by starting the mower on the man’s property, thereby making the offer irrevocable at that point.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50 because the offer for a unilateral contract became irrevocable when the neighbor started performing the task of mowing the lawn.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover the $50 after the man revoked the offer before the neighbor completed mowing the lawn?
members.rule: In a unilateral contract, an offeror's power to revoke is limited once the offeree has begun performance. The Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45 states that the offer becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance, creating an option contract.
members.application: The neighbor began performing the task by starting the lawn mower on the man's property. According to the rule in Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45, this initiation of performance made the offer irrevocable. Therefore, the man's attempted revocation after performance had begun was ineffective.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50 because the offer for a unilateral contract became irrevocable when the neighbor began performance by starting the lawn mower.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 after the man revoked his offer for mowing the lawn, given the neighbor had already begun performance?
members.rule: In unilateral contracts, once the offeree begins performance, the offeror cannot revoke the offer. The Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45 states that when an offeree begins performance in a unilateral contract, the offeror’s power to revoke the offer is suspended.
members.application: The neighbor began performance by starting to mow the lawn, which constituted acceptance of the unilateral contract offer. Under the rule, once performance begins, the offeror (the man) cannot revoke the offer. Therefore, the neighbor's action of starting the mower and being on the property constitutes beginning of performance, making the offer irrevocable at that point.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation, the neighbor can recover the $50.

representative.issue: Can the neighbor recover the $50 after the man revoked his offer as the neighbor began to mow the lawn?
representative.rule: In the context of unilateral contracts, an offer can be revoked by the offeror at any time before the offeree completes the performance that the offeror has specified. However, if the offeree has begun performance, the offer becomes irrevocable, and the offeror is obligated to allow the offeree to complete the act.
representative.application: In this scenario, the man offered to pay his neighbor $50 if the neighbor mowed his lawn, constituting a unilateral contract where the contract is only formed upon completion of the requested act (mowing the lawn). The neighbor began to perform by starting the lawn mower on the man's property, indicating commencement of performance. Under the rule of unilateral contracts, once the performance has begun, the offeror (the man) must hold the offer open until the task is completed. Therefore, the man's attempt to revoke the offer as the neighbor started the engine was ineffective.
representative.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50 because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man's attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 for mowing the lawn after the man revoked his offer?

members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man's attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover the $50 after the man revoked the offer while the neighbor was beginning to perform the task?

The neighbor began performing by starting to mow the lawn, at which point the offer became irrevocable. The neighbor also relied on the offer by purchasing gasoline, evidencing reliance.

members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50 because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man's attempted revocation.

members.rule: In a unilateral contract, once the offeree begins performance, the offeror cannot revoke the offer. This principle is supported by the doctrine of part performance, which renders the offer irrevocable once performance has started.

Under the doctrine of part performance, the man's offer became irrevocable once the neighbor began mowing the lawn, despite the man's attempt to revoke the offer.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover the $50 after the man revoked his offer as the neighbor began mowing the lawn?
members.rule: In the context of unilateral contracts, an offer can be revoked at any time before the offeree completes the performance that the offeror requests. However, once the offeree begins the performance, the offeror must hold the offer open for a reasonable time to allow the offeree to complete the performance.
members.application: In this scenario, the offer made by the man ('If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50') constitutes a unilateral contract, where the performance of mowing the lawn is required to accept the offer. The neighbor began the performance by starting to mow the lawn, which should bind the man to the offer for a reasonable time to allow completion of the task. The man's attempt to revoke the offer at that moment may not be effective because the neighbor had already begun the performance.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 from the man after the man revoked his offer when the neighbor began to perform the task of mowing the lawn.
members.rule: In a unilateral contract, an offer can be revoked at any time before performance has been completed, unless the offeror has expressly or impliedly indicated that the offer will remain open for a specific time or until performance has begun. However, once performance has commenced, the offer becomes irrevocable under the doctrine known as 'substantial performance'.
members.application: In this scenario, the neighbor began to perform the task of mowing the lawn by wheeling out his mower and starting the engine. The action of starting to perform the task typically signifies the beginning of performance under a unilateral contract. Although the man attempted to revoke his offer just as the neighbor began the task, the neighbor had already initiated performance, thereby making the offer to pay $50 for mowing the lawn irrevocable at that point.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man's attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover the $50 after the man revoked his offer, given that the neighbor had started to perform by mowing the lawn?
members.rule: In the context of unilateral contracts, an offer can be revoked by the offeror at any time before performance is completed, unless the offeree has substantially begun performance, thereby making the offer irrevocable.
members.application: In this scenario, the neighbor began the act of performance by starting to mow the lawn, which is the specific performance required to accept the offer in a unilateral contract. According to the doctrine governing unilateral contracts, once the performance has substantially begun, the offeror's power to revoke the offer terminates. Thus, when the man yelled to revoke his offer as the neighbor started mowing, the neighbor had already begun the performance, making the offer irrevocable.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover the $50 after the man revoked his offer when the neighbor had already started to mow the lawn?
members.rule: In the context of a unilateral contract, an offer can be revoked by the offeror at any time before the offeree completes the performance. However, once performance has commenced, the offer becomes irrevocable, and the offeree must be allowed to complete the task to claim the reward.
members.application: In this scenario, the neighbor began to perform the task of mowing the lawn by preparing and starting the mower on the man's property, thus commencing performance. According to the rule governing unilateral contracts, the man's attempt to revoke the offer after the neighbor had started the performance was ineffective. members.issue: Can the neighbor recover the $50 after the man revoked his offer as the neighbor began to mow the lawn?
members.rule: In the context of a unilateral contract, an offer can be revoked by the offeror at any time before the offeree has completed the performance. However, if the offeree has begun performance, the offer then becomes irrevocable under the doctrine of promissory estoppel, which prevents the offeror from withdrawing the offer if the offeree has reasonably and substantially relied on the promise by beginning performance.
members.application: In this scenario, the neighbor began to perform the requested task of mowing the lawn by moving his lawn mower to the man's property and starting the engine, which constitutes the beginning of performance. According to the doctrine of promissory estoppel, because the neighbor had begun the performance based on the man's promise, the man's attempt to revoke the offer at that moment was ineffective. The neighbor's actions of preparing and initiating the task show substantial reliance on the man's promise, thus making the offer irrevocable.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50 because the man's offer for a unilateral contract became irrevocable when the neighbor started performance, thereby entitling the neighbor to the promised compensation upon completion of the task.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover the $50 after the man revoked his offer when the neighbor had already started to mow the lawn?
members.rule: In the context of unilateral contracts, an offer can be revoked by the offeror at any time before the offeree has completed performance. However, once the offeree has begun performance, the offeror's power to revoke is typically lost under the doctrine of promissory estoppel, which prevents the offeror from revoking an offer if the offeree has reasonably relied on the promise and has partially performed.
members.application: In this scenario, the neighbor began to perform the task (mowing the lawn) by preparing and starting the lawn mower on the man's property. This act constitutes the beginning of performance. According to the doctrine of promissory estoppel, the man's attempt to revoke the offer after performance had started would typically be ineffective. The neighbor's actions of purchasing gasoline and beginning to mow the lawn indicate reliance on the man's offer and partial performance, which should prevent the man from revoking the offer.
members.conclusion: Yes, under the doctrine of promissory estoppel, the neighbor should be able to recover the $50 because he began performance before the man revoked his offer.

members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can recover the $50 because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man's attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover the $50 after the man revoked his offer, given that the neighbor had already begun to mow the lawn?
members.rule: In the context of a unilateral contract, an offer can be revoked by the offeror at any time before the offeree completes the requested performance, unless the offeree has substantially begun performance. Once substantial performance has begun, the offeror's power to revoke the offer is typically lost, based on the principle that it would be unjust to allow revocation after the offeree has incurred significant expenses or effort in reliance on the promise.

These actions constitute more than mere preparation and indicate that the neighbor had substantially begun the performance of the task. Therefore, the man's attempt to revoke the offer after these substantial steps were taken would generally be considered ineffective.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor can likely recover the $50, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man's attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after the man revoked his offer as the neighbor began to mow the lawn.
members.rule: In the context of a unilateral contract, an offer can generally be revoked by the offeror until the offeree has substantially performed the act necessary to accept the offer. representative.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 when the offeror attempted to revoke a unilateral contract offer after the neighbor began performance but before completion.
representative.rule: An offer that invites acceptance only by performance is a unilateral contract offer. Under the modern rule (Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45), once the offeree begins the invited performance, an option contract is created and the offer becomes temporarily irrevocable; the offeror must allow the offeree a reasonable opportunity to complete performance. Mere preparations to perform do not constitute beginning performance and do not make the offer irrevocable (though reliance may, in some cases, support promissory estoppel). If the offeree completes performance after beginning it, the offeror is bound to pay.
representative.application: The man’s statement (“If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50”) is an offer for a unilateral contract, inviting acceptance by completing the mowing. The neighbor’s purchase of gasoline is only preparation, but wheeling the mower onto the property and starting the engine is conduct strongly indicating the commencement of the invited performance (the mowing task). Because performance had begun, the man’s attempted revocation was ineffective under § 45, and if the neighbor thereafter completes mowing the lawn, the neighbor is entitled to the $50.
representative.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after mowing the lawn when the offeror attempted to revoke a unilateral contract offer after the neighbor began performance.
members.rule: An offer conditioned on completion of an act is an offer for a unilateral contract. members.issue: Whether an offeror can effectively revoke an offer for a unilateral contract after the offeree has made preparations and commenced the initial steps of performance (starting the engine) but before the primary task (cutting the grass) has been completed.
members.rule: A unilateral contract is formed when an offer requests performance rather than a return promise. Under the modern view (Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45), once an offeree begins the invited performance, an option contract is created, rendering the offer irrevocable and giving the offeree a reasonable time to complete the performance. Mere preparation to perform is not enough to make the offer irrevocable; the offeree must have commenced the actual performance.
members.application: Here, the man made an offer for a unilateral contract, requesting the act of mowing in exchange for $50. The neighbor's purchase of gasoline constituted mere preparation. However, by wheeling the mower to the property and starting the engine, the neighbor proceeded beyond preparation and began the requested performance. At the moment the neighbor started the engine to begin the job, the offer became an irrevocable option contract. Therefore, the man's subsequent attempt to revoke the offer was legally ineffective.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether an offeror can effectively revoke an offer for a unilateral contract after the offeree has commenced performance but has not yet completed it.
members.rule: A unilateral contract is formed by performance rather than a promise. Under modern contract law (specifically Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45), once an offeree begins the invited performance, the offer becomes an irrevocable option contract, allowing the offeree a reasonable time to complete performance. A distinction is drawn between mere preparation (which does not prevent revocation) and the commencement of performance (which makes the offer irrevocable).
members.application: The man offered $50 in exchange for the act of mowing the lawn, creating a unilateral offer. While purchasing gasoline constituted mere preparation, the neighbor subsequently wheeled the mower to the man's property and started the engine. These actions constitute the commencement of the actual performance requested, rather than mere preparation. Therefore, an option contract was formed, rendering the offer irrevocable at the moment performance began, invalidating the man's subsequent attempt to revoke.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether an offeror in a unilateral contract can validly revoke the offer after the offeree has made preparations and commenced the requested performance, but before the performance is completed.
members.rule: A unilateral contract is formed when an offeree accepts an offer by performing a requested act. Under the modern rule (Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45), once an offeree begins the actual performance (as opposed to mere preparation), an option contract is created, making the offer irrevocable for a reasonable time to allow the offeree to complete the performance.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract, seeking the act of mowing in exchange for $50. While the neighbor's purchase of gasoline was mere preparation, wheeling the mower to the property and starting the engine constituted the commencement of the performance. Because the neighbor had begun performance, the offer became an irrevocable option contract at that moment. The man's subsequent attempt to revoke was ineffective, and the neighbor validly accepted the contract by completing the mowing.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether an offeror can effectively revoke an offer for a unilateral contract after the offeree has commenced performance but before the performance is completed.
members.rule: In a unilateral contract, where an offer requests performance rather than a promise, the offer becomes an irrevocable option contract once the offeree begins the invited performance. While mere preparation is insufficient to trigger this protection, the commencement of the actual task suspends the offeror's power to revoke, provided the offeree completes the performance within a reasonable time.
members.application: The man made a unilateral offer ($50 in exchange for the act of mowing). The neighbor went beyond mere preparation (purchasing gas) and commenced performance by wheeling the mower to the property and starting the engine. At that moment, the offer became irrevocable. Therefore, the man's subsequent attempt to revoke was ineffective, and the neighbor is entitled to the contract price upon completing the job.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether an offeror can validly revoke an offer for a unilateral contract after the offeree has taken steps to commence the requested performance but has not yet completed it.
members.rule: In a unilateral contract, the offer is accepted by performance rather than by a promise. Under the modern view (Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45), once the offeree begins the requested performance, an option contract is created, making the offer irrevocable for a reasonable time to allow the offeree to complete performance. While mere preparation is insufficient to bar revocation, the actual commencement of the specific task requested suspends the offeror's power to revoke.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract, conditioning payment on the act of mowing. While the neighbor's purchase of gasoline constituted mere preparation, wheeling the mower onto the property and starting the engine constituted the beginning of performance. Because the neighbor had commenced the requested task, the offer became irrevocable at that moment. The man's subsequent attempt to shout a revocation was ineffective because the power to revoke had already been suspended by the neighbor's commencement of performance.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether an offeror may effectively revoke an offer for a unilateral contract after the offeree has commenced performance of the requested act but before the act is completed.
members.rule: In a unilateral contract, the offeror requests performance rather than a promise. Under modern contract law (Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45), once an offeree begins the requested performance, an option contract is created, making the offer irrevocable for a reasonable time to allow the offeree to complete the performance. Mere preparation to perform is insufficient to make the offer irrevocable, but the actual commencement of the task renders the revocation ineffective.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract, conditioning payment on the act of mowing the lawn. While the neighbor's purchase of gasoline was merely preparation, bringing the mower to the property and starting the engine constituted the beginning of the requested performance. Because performance had begun, the offer became irrevocable by operation of law at that moment. Consequently, the man's subsequent attempt to revoke was ineffective, and the neighbor perfected acceptance by completing the job.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

representative.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 from the man for mowing his lawn after the man revoked his offer?
representative.rule: An offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable if the offeree has begun performance. Beginning performance creates an option contract, making the offer irrevocable for a reasonable time.
representative.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract by saying, 'If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50.' The neighbor started performance by preparing to mow the lawn and starting the engine on his mower. This act constituted beginning performance, making the offer irrevocable. The man's subsequent revocation was ineffective because the neighbor had already begun performance.
representative.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Is the man's revocation of his offer effective, and is the neighbor entitled to $50 for mowing the lawn?
members.rule: An offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance. The beginning of performance creates an option contract, binding the offeror to keep the offer open.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract by promising to pay $50 if the neighbor mowed his lawn. The neighbor began performance by starting the engine of his lawn mower on the man's property, thus creating an option contract. The man's subsequent revocation of his offer is ineffective because the neighbor had already begun performance.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man's attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 for mowing the man's lawn after the man revoked his offer?
members.rule: An offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance. The beginning of performance creates an option contract, binding the offeror to keep the offer open.
members.application: The man's statement, 'If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50,' is an offer for a unilateral contract. The neighbor began performance by preparing to mow the lawn and starting the engine on his property. This constitutes the beginning of performance, making the offer irrevocable. Therefore, the man's revocation was ineffective.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 from the man for mowing the lawn after the man revoked his offer?
members.rule: An offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance. The beginning of performance creates an option contract, binding the offeror to keep the offer open.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract by saying, 'If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50.' The neighbor started performance by preparing to mow the lawn and beginning the task. However, merely purchasing gasoline and wheeling the lawn mower to the man's property and starting the engine may be considered preparation rather than the beginning of performance. The key is whether these actions constitute the start of performance. In this case, starting the engine is a substantial step towards performance and can be considered the beginning of performance.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 from the man for mowing his lawn after the man revoked his offer?

The man's subsequent revocation was ineffective because the neighbor had already begun performance.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 from the man for mowing his lawn after the man revoked his offer?
members.rule: An offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable if the offeree has begun performance. To be considered as having begun performance, the offeree must have taken substantial steps towards completing the requested task, not just preparing to do so.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract by saying, 'If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50.' The neighbor started the process by purchasing gasoline and wheeling his lawn mower to the man's property and starting the engine, which constitutes beginning performance. Since the neighbor had begun performance before the man revoked his offer, the offer became irrevocable.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 from the man for mowing the lawn after the man revoked his offer?
members.rule: An offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance. The beginning of performance creates an option contract, binding the offeror to keep the offer open.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract by saying, 'If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50.' The neighbor began performance by starting the engine of his lawn mower on the man's property. This act constituted the beginning of performance, making the offer irrevocable. Therefore, the man's revocation was ineffective.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 from the man for mowing his lawn after the man revoked his offer.
members.rule: An offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable if the offeree has begun performance. Beginning performance creates an option contract, making the offer irrevocable until the offeree has had a reasonable time to complete performance.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract to the neighbor by saying, 'If you will mow my lawn, I will pay you $50.' The neighbor started performance by wheeling his lawn mower to the man's property and starting the engine before the man attempted to revoke his offer. Starting the engine constitutes beginning performance, thus making the offer irrevocable.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

members.issue: Can the neighbor recover $50 for mowing the man's lawn despite the man's revocation of his offer?
members.rule: An offer for a unilateral contract can generally be revoked at any time before the offeree begins performance, unless the offeror has made an option contract or the offeree has substantially begun performance.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract to the neighbor, promising to pay $50 if the neighbor mows his lawn. The neighbor began preparations and started the mower, but had not completed the task. Under the modern rule, an offer for a unilateral contract becomes irrevocable if the offeree begins performance. However, merely preparing to perform is not enough; the offeree must substantially begin performance. In this case, the neighbor had started the engine, which is considered the beginning of performance, making the offer irrevocable.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man’s attempted revocation.

representative.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after mowing the lawn when the man attempted to revoke his offer after the neighbor started the mower but before completing performance of a unilateral contract.
representative.rule: Under contract law, an offer for a unilateral contract (one seeking performance rather than a promise) traditionally could be revoked anytime before complete performance. However, the modern rule, as expressed in Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45, provides that once an offeree begins performance of a unilateral contract, the offeror's power to revoke is suspended, and the offer becomes temporarily irrevocable to give the offeree a reasonable time to complete performance. Mere preparation to perform does not trigger this protection; the offeree must actually begin the invited performance itself.
representative.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract, seeking the act of mowing the lawn rather than a promise to mow. The neighbor's purchase of gasoline constituted mere preparation, not performance. However, when the neighbor wheeled the mower to the property and started the engine, he began the actual performance of mowing the lawn. Starting the mower on the man's property constitutes the beginning of performance, not mere preparation. Under § 45, this commencement of performance rendered the offer temporarily irrevocable, preventing the man's attempted revocation. The neighbor then completed performance by mowing the lawn, thereby accepting the offer and forming a binding contract entitling him to the $50.
representative.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor will recover the $50 because the offer for a unilateral contract became irrevocable when he began performance by starting the mower, making the man's subsequent attempted revocation ineffective.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after mowing the man's lawn when the man attempted to revoke his offer after the neighbor had started the engine but before completing performance.
members.rule: Under contract law, an offer for a unilateral contract is accepted by complete performance, not by a promise to perform. Traditionally, such offers could be revoked at any time before complete performance. However, under modern contract law and the Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45, once an offeree begins performance of a unilateral contract, the offeror's power to revoke is suspended, and the offer becomes temporarily irrevocable to give the offeree a reasonable time to complete performance. Beginning performance creates an option contract. Mere preparation to perform, however, does not trigger this protection—the offeree must actually begin the invited performance itself.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract that could only be accepted by the neighbor's complete performance of mowing the lawn. The neighbor purchased gasoline (mere preparation) and wheeled the mower to the property (still preparation). The critical moment is when the neighbor started the engine. Starting the mower's engine on the man's property constitutes the beginning of the actual performance of mowing the lawn, not mere preparation. Once the neighbor began performance by starting the engine, under § 45, the man's offer became temporarily irrevocable, and the man's attempted revocation was ineffective. The neighbor then completed performance by mowing the lawn, thereby accepting the offer and forming a binding contract.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor will recover the $50 because the offer for a unilateral contract became irrevocable when the neighbor began performance by starting the engine, rendering the man's subsequent attempted revocation ineffective.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 when the man revoked his offer for a unilateral contract after the neighbor had started performance but before completion.
members.rule: Under the doctrine of unilateral contracts, an offer for a unilateral contract (one seeking performance rather than a promise) becomes irrevocable once the offeree begins performance, not mere preparation. The Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45 provides that an option contract is created when the offeree begins the invited performance, making the offer temporarily irrevocable for a reasonable time to complete performance. Mere preparation to perform does not create this irrevocability. Starting the actual invited act (mowing) constitutes beginning performance, while purchasing gasoline or moving equipment to the location constitutes only preparation.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract, promising $50 in exchange for the completed performance of mowing the lawn. The neighbor's purchase of gasoline and wheeling the mower to the property constituted mere preparation, not the beginning of performance. However, when the neighbor started the lawn mower engine, he began the actual invited performance of mowing the lawn. Under § 45, this beginning of performance created an option contract, rendering the man's offer irrevocable for a reasonable time to allow completion. The man's attempted revocation after the neighbor started the engine was therefore ineffective. By completing the mowing after the purported revocation, the neighbor accepted the offer and is entitled to the promised compensation.
members.conclusion: Yes, because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man's attempted revocation.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after mowing the man's lawn when the man attempted to revoke his offer after the neighbor started the mower but before completing performance of a unilateral contract.
members.rule: An offer for a unilateral contract is accepted only by complete performance, not by beginning performance or preparing to perform. However, under modern contract law (Restatement Second of Contracts § 45), once an offeree begins performance of a unilateral contract, the offeror's power to revoke is suspended, and the offer becomes temporarily irrevocable to give the offeree a reasonable opportunity to complete performance. Mere preparation to perform does not trigger this protection; the offeree must actually begin the invited performance itself.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract: performance (mowing the lawn) in exchange for payment ($50). The neighbor's purchase of gasoline and wheeling the mower to the property constitute mere preparation, not the beginning of the actual performance of mowing. However, starting the mower's engine can be considered the beginning of performance of the act of mowing the lawn itself. Once the neighbor started the engine—beginning the performance—the man's power to revoke was suspended under § 45. The man's attempted revocation at that moment was therefore ineffective. By completing the mowing after the attempted revocation, the neighbor accepted the offer and formed a binding contract entitling him to the $50.
members.conclusion: Yes, the neighbor will recover the $50 because there was an offer for a unilateral contract that became irrevocable prior to the man's attempted revocation when the neighbor began performance by starting the mower engine.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after mowing the lawn when the man attempted to revoke his offer after the neighbor started the mower but before completing performance of a unilateral contract.
members.rule: Under the common law of unilateral contracts, an offer for a unilateral contract (one seeking performance rather than a promise) can ordinarily be revoked at any time before complete performance. However, under the modern rule adopted in Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 45, once an offeree begins performance of a unilateral contract, the offeror's power to revoke is suspended, and the offer becomes temporarily irrevocable for a reasonable time to complete performance. Mere preparation for performance does not trigger this protection; the offeree must actually begin the invited performance itself.
members.application: The man made an offer for a unilateral contract, seeking the act of mowing the lawn rather than a promise to mow. The neighbor's purchase of gasoline and wheeling the mower to the property constituted mere preparation, not the beginning of actual performance. However, starting the mower's engine on the man's property constitutes the beginning of the actual performance of mowing the lawn. Under Restatement § 45, once the neighbor started the engine (beginning performance), the man's offer became temporarily irrevocable. The man's attempted revocation at that moment was therefore ineffective. Since the neighbor thereafter completed the performance by mowing the lawn, and the offer could not be validly revoked, a unilateral contract was formed upon completion of performance.
members.conclusion: Yes, because the neighbor had begun the invited performance (not mere preparation) before the man attempted revocation, making the offer temporarily irrevocable under the doctrine applicable to unilateral contracts, and the neighbor completed performance thereafter, forming a binding contract entitling him to the $50.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after mowing the man's lawn when the man attempted to revoke his offer after the neighbor had started the engine but before completing performance.
members.rule: Under contract law, an offer for a unilateral contract is accepted by complete performance, not by a promise to perform. However, under the modern rule (Restatement Second of Contracts § 45), once an offeree begins performance of a unilateral contract, the offer becomes irrevocable for a reasonable time to complete performance. Beginning performance creates an option contract that prevents revocation. Mere preparation to perform does not constitute beginning performance and does not make the offer irrevocable.

However, starting the engine on the man's property constitutes the beginning of the actual performance of mowing the lawn. At the moment the neighbor started the engine, he began performance, thereby triggering the rule that makes the offer irrevocable. The man's attempted revocation came after the neighbor had already begun performance by starting the engine. Therefore, the revocation was ineffective, and the neighbor's subsequent completion of the lawn mowing constitutes full performance of the unilateral contract, entitling him to the $50.

members.issue: Whether the neighbor can recover $50 after mowing the lawn when the man revoked his offer after the neighbor started the mower's engine but before completing the lawn mowing.
members.rule: Under traditional contract law, an offer for a unilateral contract can be accepted only by complete performance, not by beginning performance or mere preparation. Mere preparation to perform does not trigger this protection; the offeree must actually begin the invited performance itself. The invited performance here is mowing the lawn, not purchasing gasoline or bringing equipment.

Starting the mower's engine, while closer to performance, is still preparatory—the actual invited performance is mowing the lawn itself.
